content.raw:
It's tough to give an error message for this because it fails at such a low level of gazebo. If I roslaunch with `--verbose`:
~~~
$ roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch extra_gazebo_args:="--verbose -u"
...
[Err] [Server.cc:284] Could not open file[atlas.world]
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp:101: boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex(): Assertion `!pthread_mutex_destroy(&m)' failed.
~~~
it complains about not being able to find the world file. It also won't be able to find any of the plugins, so we can't put an error message there.

For reference, here's the backtrace from that mutex assertion on my trusty machine. It seems to involve CEGUI.
~~~
Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
0x00007ffff4f1cbb9 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
56	../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff4f1cbb9 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
#1  0x00007ffff4f1ffc8 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89
#2  0x00007ffff4f15a76 in __assert_fail_base (fmt=0x7ffff5067370 "%s%s%s:%u: %s%sAssertion `%s' failed.\n%n", 
    assertion=assertion@entry=0x7fffe85c4665 "!pthread_mutex_destroy(&m)", 
    file=file@entry=0x7fffe85c46e8 "/usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp", line=line@entry=101, 
    function=function@entry=0x7fffe85c4f20 "boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex()") at assert.c:92
#3  0x00007ffff4f15b22 in __GI___assert_fail (assertion=0x7fffe85c4665 "!pthread_mutex_destroy(&m)", 
    file=0x7fffe85c46e8 "/usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp", line=101, 
    function=0x7fffe85c4f20 "boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex()") at assert.c:101
#4  0x00007fffe85b9da1 in boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex() () from /usr/lib/libCEGUIOgreRenderer-0.7.6.so
#5  0x00007ffff4f22149 in __run_exit_handlers (status=-1, listp=0x7ffff52a56c8 <__exit_funcs>, 
    run_list_atexit=run_list_atexit@entry=true) at exit.c:82
#6  0x00007ffff4f22195 in __GI_exit (status=<optimized out>) at exit.c:104
#7  0x00007ffff4f07ecc in __libc_start_main (main=0x40cf30, argc=7, argv=0x7fffffffd998, init=<optimized out>, 
    fini=<optimized out>, rtld_fini=<optimized out>, stack_end=0x7fffffffd988) at libc-start.c:321
#8  0x000000000040ee18 in _start ()
~~~

It's tough to give an error message for this because it fails at such a low level of gazebo. If I roslaunch with --verbose:

it complains about not being able to find the world file. It also won't be able to find any of the plugins, so we can't put an error message there.

content.raw: The problem might be in `libgazebo_ros_api_plugin`. I modified the `run_gazebo` script. Without `-s libgazebo_ros_api_plugins.so`, gazebo will output an error but it won't crash.
content.html: The problem might be in libgazebo_ros_api_plugin. I modified the run_gazebo script. Without -s libgazebo_ros_api_plugins.so, gazebo will output an error but it won't crash.

content.raw:
Jackie, if I source /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh I can indeed run the Atlas sims.  I had taken that our of my .bashrc as DRCSim was causing problems with other robots (see below).


There are many Gazebo robots that work fine under Gazebo 2 that no longer work under Gazebo 4.  That's the problem I'm struggling with.

Take the r2_gazebo simulator for example.  Using the standard ros-indigo-simulators packages, it works fine.  With Gazebo 4, I get this same error.  So at this point, we have to have a partition for running DRCSim, and a whole separate partition for running ANY OTHER Gazebo robot that just uses the ros-indigo-simulators package because I can't have both drcsim's Gazebo 4 and ros-indigio-simulator's Gazebo2 installed at the same time.  

```
pbeeson@tardis:~/projects/sims$ . /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh
pbeeson@tardis:~/projects/sims$ roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch 
.
.
.
[INFO] [WallTime: 1423604702.448153] [0.000000] Waiting for service /gazebo/spawn_urdf_model
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp:101: boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex(): Assertion `!pthread_mutex_destroy(&m)' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)
```
content.html:
Jackie, if I source /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh I can indeed run the Atlas sims. I had taken that our of my .bashrc as DRCSim was causing problems with other robots (see below).

There are many Gazebo robots that work fine under Gazebo 2 that no longer work under Gazebo 4. That's the problem I'm struggling with.

Take the r2_gazebo simulator for example. Using the standard ros-indigo-simulators packages, it works fine. With Gazebo 4, I get this same error. So at this point, we have to have a partition for running DRCSim, and a whole separate partition for running ANY OTHER Gazebo robot that just uses the ros-indigo-simulators package because I can't have both drcsim's Gazebo 4 and ros-indigio-simulator's Gazebo2 installed at the same time. 

pbeeson@tardis:~/projects/sims$ . /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh
pbeeson@tardis:~/projects/sims$ roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch 
.
.
.
[INFO] [WallTime: 1423604702.448153] [0.000000] Waiting for service /gazebo/spawn_urdf_model
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp:101: boost::recursive_mutex::~recursive_mutex(): Assertion `!pthread_mutex_destroy(&m)' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)

content.raw:
With the drcsim 4.2.0-2~trusty deb, I can confirm the failure when I run the following:
~~~
roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas_v4_bringup.launch
~~~
but is that launch file intended to be used directly? I know it is included by other launch files. The following works for me:
~~~
roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch model_args:=_v4
~~~
Could this be a case of using the wrong launch files?

I'll test the r2 simulator as well.
content.html:
With the drcsim 4.2.0-2~trusty deb, I can confirm the failure when I run the following:

roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas_v4_bringup.launch

but is that launch file intended to be used directly? I know it is included by other launch files. The following works for me:

roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch model_args:=_v4

Could this be a case of using the wrong launch files?

I'll test the r2 simulator as well.

content.raw: I'm running the "indigo" branches of the the two r2 bitbucket repos (nasa_r2_common, nasa_r2_simulators).  These were working before this gazebo error cropped up this morning.  There should be corresponding "hydro" branches as well.
content.html: I'm running the "indigo" branches of the the two r2 bitbucket repos (nasa_r2_common, nasa_r2_simulators). These were working before this gazebo error cropped up this morning. There should be corresponding "hydro" branches as well.

content.raw:
Looks like a shutdown issue, proper environment path setup avoids this error. Is this blocking?

Looking at the original bug report, it seems the failure is triggered by not being able to find the world file, subsequently some component failed to shutdown properly and producing the error.

~~~
$ roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch extra_gazebo_args:="--verbose" gzname:="gzserver_gdb"
...
[Err] [Server.cc:285] Could not open file[atlas.world]
...
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fffb67fc700 (LWP 20489)]
__memcpy_sse2_unaligned ()
    at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memcpy-sse2-unaligned.S:36
36	../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memcpy-sse2-unaligned.S: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  __memcpy_sse2_unaligned ()
    at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memcpy-sse2-unaligned.S:36
#1  0x00007ffff537ffa0 in std::string::_Rep::_M_clone(std::allocator<char> const&, unsigned long) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#2  0x00007ffff53805fc in std::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >::basic_string(std::string const&) ()
   from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#3  0x00007fffd9419d64 in ros::param::getImpl(std::string const&, XmlRpc::XmlRpcValue&, bool) () from /opt/ros/indigo/lib/libroscpp.so
#4  0x00007fffd941ad59 in ros::param::getImpl(std::string const&, double&, bool) () from /opt/ros/indigo/lib/libroscpp.so
#5  0x00007fffd945bf9c in ros::NodeHandle::getParam(std::string const&, double&) const () from /opt/ros/indigo/lib/libroscpp.so
#6  0x00007fffd99ac67b in gazebo_ros::PhysicsConfig::__fromServer__(ros::NodeHandle const&) ()
   from /home/hsu/projects/catkin_drcsim_drcsim4_release/install/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so
#7  0x00007fffd99ae04f in dynamic_reconfigure::Server<gazebo_ros::PhysicsConfig>::init() ()
   from /home/hsu/projects/catkin_drcsim_drcsim4_release/install/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so
#8  0x00007fffd9973b40 in gazebo::GazeboRosApiPlugin::physicsReconfigureThread() ()
   from /home/hsu/projects/catkin_drcsim_drcsim4_release/install/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so

#11 0x00007ffff4ade00d in clone ()

(gdb) 
~~~

reiterating the error:
~~~
$ roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch extra_gazebo_args:="--verbose" 
...
[Err] [Server.cc:285] Could not open file[atlas.world]
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >'
  what():  boost: mutex unlock failed in pthread_mutex_unlock: Invalid argument
[gazebo-1] process has died [pid 21036, exit code 255, cmd /home/hsu/projects/catkin_drcsim_drcsim4_release/install/share/drcsim_gazebo/scripts/run_gazebo atlas.world --verbose __name:=gazebo __log:=/home/hsu/.ros/log/bc7187c6-b173-11e4-8d3b-d0509919a838/gazebo-1.log].

content.raw: On the issue of using non-Atlas robots with Gazebo4, this is NOT a missing world file.  You can simply reinstall Gazebo 2 (blowing away DRCSim) and run the r2_gazebo launch file successfully , then reinstall DRCSIM/Gazebo 4 and run r2_gazebo and get this error.
content.html: On the issue of using non-Atlas robots with Gazebo4, this is NOT a missing world file. You can simply reinstall Gazebo 2 (blowing away DRCSim) and run the r2_gazebo launch file successfully , then reinstall DRCSIM/Gazebo 4 and run r2_gazebo and get this error.

content.raw:
just as an experiment, i started up atlas (using gazebo 4 and our own ros plugins, not the libgazebo_ros_api.so, and without drcsim on my system), and then ran the r2 sim, and it works (i.e., i have both robots running in gazebo, and dont get the boost error).

I do get a new error, but i think this is just related to me blindly trying to start two gzservers at the same time:

```
[gazebo-1] process has died [pid 17607, exit code 255, cmd /opt/ros/indigo/lib/gazebo_ros/gzserver /home/swhart/ros/catkin_workspace/src/nasa_r2_simulator/r2_gazebo/gazebo/r2_empty.world __name:=gazebo __log:=/home/swhart/.ros/log/0533a6f0-b175-11e4-b6fe-f0761c1354e1/gazebo-1.log].
log file: /home/swhart/.ros/log/0533a6f0-b175-11e4-b6fe-f0761c1354e1/gazebo-1*.log

```

just as an experiment, i started up atlas (using gazebo 4 and our own ros plugins, not the libgazebo_ros_api.so, and without drcsim on my system), and then ran the r2 sim, and it works (i.e., i have both robots running in gazebo, and dont get the boost error).

I do get a new error, but i think this is just related to me blindly trying to start two gzservers at the same time:

[gazebo-1] process has died [pid 17607, exit code 255, cmd /opt/ros/indigo/lib/gazebo_ros/gzserver /home/swhart/ros/catkin_workspace/src/nasa_r2_simulator/r2_gazebo/gazebo/r2_empty.world __name:=gazebo __log:=/home/swhart/.ros/log/0533a6f0-b175-11e4-b6fe-f0761c1354e1/gazebo-1.log].

content.raw:
@pbeeson regarding `r2_gazebo`

~~~
On the issue of using non-Atlas robots with Gazebo4, this is NOT a missing world file. You can simply reinstall Gazebo 2 (blowing away DRCSim) and run the r2_gazebo launch file successfully , then reinstall DRCSIM/Gazebo 4 and run r2_gazebo and get this error.
~~~

for your setup with gazebo 4 and r2_gazebo, instead of sourcing `.../drcsim/setup.sh`, can you try sourcing `[install target]/share/gazebo/setup.sh` before running r2_gazebo and see if it resolves the issue for you?  (I am trying to guess some linking path/flag changed in gazebo 4).
content.html:
@pbeeson regarding r2_gazebo

On the issue of using non-Atlas robots with Gazebo4, this is NOT a missing world file. You can simply reinstall Gazebo 2 (blowing away DRCSim) and run the r2_gazebo launch file successfully , then reinstall DRCSIM/Gazebo 4 and run r2_gazebo and get this error.

for your setup with gazebo 4 and r2_gazebo, instead of sourcing .../drcsim/setup.sh, can you try sourcing [install target]/share/gazebo/setup.sh before running r2_gazebo and see if it resolves the issue for you? (I am trying to guess some linking path/flag changed in gazebo 4).

content.raw: As @hsu said, this error occurs when the world file cannot be found (the `--verbose` flag will indicate that). There are some problems with r2_gazebo repository that are unrelated to drcsim. I will fix them, but I haven't been able to reproduce @pbeeson 's problem unless I use the `atlas_v4_bringup.launch` file.
content.html: As @hsu said, this error occurs when the world file cannot be found (the --verbose flag will indicate that). There are some problems with r2_gazebo repository that are unrelated to drcsim. I will fix them, but I haven't been able to reproduce @pbeeson 's problem unless I use the atlas_v4_bringup.launch file.

@swhart115

If the world file error exists, that seems to be the main cause of segfault. The boost error is an artifact of a bad shutdown of multiple components on different threads/processes.

@pbeeson

can you post the console error outputs, and check if there is a "world not found" error in your setup too?

Thanks!

content.raw:
@swhart115

~~~
So is the issue that I pulled an update this morning that fails on not finding the world file, rather then just proceeding without one?
~~~

I think the issues here might be:

  - something you pulled this morning caused the world file to not be found. Can you double check if this is an error caused by changes in gazebo?
  - when gazebo world is not found on simulation startup, the boost mutex error on shutdown is not nice and is confusing.
content.html:
@swhart115

So is the issue that I pulled an update this morning that fails on not finding the world file, rather then just proceeding without one?

I think the issues here might be:

  • something you pulled this morning caused the world file to not be found. Can you double check if this is an error caused by changes in gazebo?
  • when gazebo world is not found on simulation startup, the boost mutex error on shutdown is not nice and is confusing.

content.raw:
The log files contain the necessary information. We don't output  to the command line by default because:

1. Constant messages get ignored over time. 
1. When running with ROS, which throws lots of garbage to the screen, Gazebo messages are lost in the noise.
1. As we move toward Windows and an icon-launchable application, console output is less useful.
content.html:
The log files contain the necessary information. We don't output to the command line by default because:

  1. Constant messages get ignored over time.
  2. When running with ROS, which throws lots of garbage to the screen, Gazebo messages are lost in the noise.
  3. As we move toward Windows and an icon-launchable application, console output is less useful.

@nkoenig I see ROS console output as a feature, maybe I am in the minority :) All joking aside, I guess we should:

  1. fix the segfault caused by missing world (whether we need to patch plugin or patch gazebo), and/or
  2. consider starting gazebo with an empty world when the user specified world is not found. This seems to be the default behavior of many different applications (e.g. meshlab, evince, etc.).

content.raw:
simple experiment with a non-existent world indicates `libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so` causes the bad shutdown behavior:

~~~
$ gazebo -s libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so a.world
[ INFO] [1423614989.046425094]: Finished loading Gazebo ROS API Plugin.
[ INFO] [1423614989.114976273]: waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] has not been advertised, waiting...
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >'
  what():  boost: mutex unlock failed in pthread_mutex_unlock: Invalid argument
$ gazebo a.world
pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception
~~~

[gazebo_ros_pkgs issue created](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/295)
content.html:
simple experiment with a non-existent world indicates libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so causes the bad shutdown behavior:

$ gazebo -s libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so a.world
[ INFO] [1423614989.046425094]: Finished loading Gazebo ROS API Plugin.
[ INFO] [1423614989.114976273]: waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] has not been advertised, waiting...
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >'
  what():  boost: mutex unlock failed in pthread_mutex_unlock: Invalid argument
$ gazebo a.world
pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception

gazebo_ros_pkgs issue created
